is a small, historic town in the borough of Dudley in the
. It is located on the south-western edge of the conurbation of industrial towns known as the Black Country.
Stourbridge was historically in the county of

county in 1974. There has been settlement in various parts of what now makes up the town for hundreds of years, particularly in the region of the bridge over the River Stour, and in Oldswinford to the south. The area became famous for its glass production in the seventeenth century after Huguenot glass makers, fleeing religious persecution in

, found the local clay, lime and coal to be ideally suited to glassmaking. Today there are still many glass producers in the area, as well as several museums, and the Stourbridge Canal was built into the town centre to facilitate trade. 

Today, alongside artisan glass makers in the Glass Quarter, the town exists as a local hub for retail and leisure. The town now includes several areas such as Norton, Lye, Pedmore, Amblecote, Wordsley and Wollaston.

Stourbridge Town station is situated within the new Stourbridge Interchange bus station. Buses run to/from here to many destinations, including
. Particularly important is the number 9 bus, which runs regularly from central
Stourbridge is easily accessed from Birmingham or the M5 via the A456 through
, continuing to Kidderminster. The A491 runs through Stourbridge from Wolverhampton in the North to Bromsgrove in the South, and the A458 runs from Birmingham through Stourbridge on to

.
Once you have reached Stourbridge, you will need to negotiate the three-lane, clockwise ring road. The town centre can be accessed most easily from the south-eastern corner, and short-stay parking is sometimes available on the High Street. A multistorey car park is available on Victoria Street, on the southern stretch of ring road.
Stourbridge town centre is most easily explored on foot. Some of the glass-based attractions are in Amblecote and Wordsley, approximately 1-2 miles to the north - regular buses run this route.
